texts.shortText: Forms stiff, upright, greenish tufts on the lower levels of exposed rocky shores, these becoming purplish towards their bases (revealing that this is a red, not a green alga!). The upright shafts emerge from a matt of creeping rhizomes and are typically about 3 mm in diameter. Each upright is irregularly branched and bears numerous short, spiky lateral projections towards its tip.

Global: Southern Africa and widely distributed in Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia (and possibly into Angola) and all along the South African coast.

Very distinctive and common species on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore, particularly on the south and east coasts, where it can form a distinct green band. Less common and less vivid green on the west coast. Often found in areas subject to sand inundation.

Has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
Spore producing structures (tetrasporangia) concentrated in the spiniform appendages branching from the ends of the main uprights.

This genus contains about 8 regional species, some of which are very difficult to tell apart. Although these have been partially resolved in a genetic study by Johnson (see references) this work appears not to have been formally published. This species can be distinguished from other local members of the genus by its stiffer and much thicker stems (3 mm vs less than 1 mm).
